keyTakeAways: Nicholas Rossi, a 38-year-old man, was sentenced to five years to life in prison for raping two women in northern Utah in 2008.
Rossi allegedly faked his death in 2020, with an online obituary claiming he died of non-Hodgkin lymphoma, which authorities later disproved.
He fled the U.S. and was arrested in Scotland in 2021 due to distinctive tattoos recognized via an Interpol notice.
He used multiple aliases, including Arthur Knight, to evade capture and was previously wanted in Rhode Island for failing to register as a sex offender.
Rossi is described as a 'serial abuser of women' and 'a flight risk,' with victims reporting financial manipulation and abuse prior to the rape.
The case is significant because it highlights the challenges of solving rape cases in a backlog system and the dangers posed by individuals who use deception to avoid accountability.
The victim testified that Rossi used manipulation and debt to control her, and raped her after an engagement, which led to her eventual reporting the crime.
This case reflects broader concerns about gender-based violence, legal system failures in tracking repeat offenders, and the importance of DNA database use in solving old crimes.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Nicholas Rossi, a 38-year-old man from Rhode Island, was sentenced to five years to life in prison in Utah after being convicted of raping two women in 2008. He had previously faked his death in 2020, with an online obituary claiming he died of non-Hodgkin lymphoma, but was later identified through a DNA rape kit and arrested in Scotland due to distinctive tattoos linked to an Interpol notice. He used multiple aliases, including Arthur Knight, to evade capture and had a history of failing to register as a sex offender. Prosecutors described him as a 'serial abuser' and 'flight risk,' while the victim testified about manipulation, financial coercion, and abuse. The case highlights the importance of DNA backlog investigations and international cooperation in solving sexual crimes, as well as the broader issue of accountability for repeat offenders who attempt to flee justice.
title: Man accused of faking his own death and fleeing the US after rape charges gets at least five years in prison
